I should confess that I never really read
any detective fiction until about ten years

8.96.text:
ago and during my talk I’m going to explain
how I came to start reading detective fiction

14.62.text:
and why I have become so fascinated by it.
But I want to start out with the archetypal

22.79.text:
Sherlock Holmes of course, the creation of
a young doctor who went on to become Sir Arthur

28.65.text:
Conan Doyle, claimed he was heavily influenced
by Wilkie Collins, Edgar Allan Poe, and Emile

37.45.text:
Gaboriau as his predecessors in writing detective
fiction. And Holmes first appeared, as you

44.11.text:
probably know, in Beaton’s Christmas Annual
in 1887. The short piece was called ‘A Study

53.28.text:
in Scarlet’ and it was not an immediate
success. However, as he gradually published

60.53.text:
more short stories in The Strand magazine,
Holmes became a phenomenon to such a degree

65.73.text:
that when in 1893 he killed him off, he then
had to bring, Conan Doyle had to bring Holmes

71.89.text:
back from the dead because subscriptions to
The Strand magazine plummeted and Conan Doyle

79.14.text:
very very reluctantly bowed to public opinion.
Once Holmes had been brought back to Baker

86.56.text:
Street and to his large body of fans, Conan
Doyle continued to write stories featuring

92.97.text:
Holmes and Dr Watson until shortly before
his death in 1930. But it’s interesting

98.34.text:
that in the preface to his last collection
of stories that came out in 1927, he made

106.14.text:
the following statement, “I fear that Mr
Sherlock Holmes may become like one of those

113.45.text:
popular tenors who, having outlived their
time, are still tempted to make repeated farewell

120.80.text:
bows to their indulgent audiences. This must
cease and he must go the way of all flesh,

130.91.text:
Now the heavy irony of this preface serves

136.48.text:
that Conan Doyle had for his creation who
seemed to have acquired a life beyond the

142.13.text:
page and of course, as we all know well, Holmes’
afterlife has continued apace. Other writers

148.82.text:
have continued to produce stories of his adventures.
Anthony Horowitz has just written two novels

156.57.text:
in the Holmes series. There was the successful
BBC television series, Sherlock, written by

163.31.text:
Mark Gatiss, Steven Moffat and Stephen Thompson,
with Martin Freeman and Benedict Cumberbatch

169.99.text:
Conan Doyle’s detective fiction has been
so frequently translated into other languages

175.99.text:
that is name is listed as fourteenth in the

182.81.text:
in the world. But even his success pales when

189.55.text:
writer, Agatha Christie. The Index Translationum

196.13.text:

203.26.text:
world author of all time’ after the Bible

209.37.text:

216.94.text:
and the English spinster, Miss Jane Marple,
have been recreated many, many times for television,

223.24.text:
for the cinema, and I don’t think there
is a single week of the year that you cannot

229.87.text:
go on UK TV and not find a repeat of Poirot
or Miss Marples. I see people nodding. But

as with Conan Doyle, Agatha Christie had initial
problems finding a publisher. She was then

244.47.text:
signed up by R. John Lane and he was the co-editor

contracted, having been signed up, to do six
novels. So Hercule Poirot appears in 1920,

265.72.text:
I’m starting with this because I think it’s

271.24.text:
about detective fiction generally if we start

281.51.text:
In 2012 the journalist Mark Lawson made a
fifteen part BBC Radio 4 series, Foreign Bodies

288.24.text:
- I don’t know if anyone heard it? - which
explored aspects of European history through

292.54.text:
a range of well-known detectives. He started
out with Sherlock Holmes of course and ended

298.20.text:
it with Harry Hole, the detective created
by one of today’s best-selling crime writers,

303.71.text:
the Norwegian Jo Nesbo, whose sales figures
globally by the way are estimate at over 50

310.79.text:
million. In an essay published in The Guardian,
Lawson points out that crime novels routinely

316.61.text:
provide a mass of minute social detail which
means that we can look at them as case files

324.72.text:
of their times and I quote, “crime fiction
is a magnifying glass that frequently reveals

332.52.text:
the fingerprints of history before they become
visible to politicians or journalists, and,

338.90.text:
as in a forensic investigation, separate pieces

347.56.text:
and to illustrate this Lawson notes that Ian

353.05.text:
depicted the ways in which Scotland began

of a century leading up to the independence

370.68.text:

379.70.text:
of being the only Western democracy to have
both its Prime Minister and Foreign Minister

386.04.text:
assassinated in modern times, or why a racist

394.02.text:
will find clues to the forces behind those
events in crime novels written at least a

401.66.text:
Now Lawson’s interest is in tracing patterns

particularly interested in the visible connections

Montalban, who created the Barcelona private

that his detective Kurt Wallander derives

the detective novels by the other Swedish

for the highly intelligent yet deeply damaged,

or Josef Skvorecky’s Inspector Boruvka.
But then he kind of goes off a bit at a tangent

and says, “however, one of probably the

- or crime detectives I should say - ‘is

486.24.text:

of course, what we have with the Sherlock

these, is we have the character of Dr Watson

universal tendency of leading crime novelists

places such as cruises down the Nile. When

570.09.text:
that has been one of the most successful of

points out that she depicted her characters

585.29.text:
audience was never likely to experience”.
So what he implies is that Christie wrote

history of war time collaboration during the

Now Lawson’s radio series stressed both

632.95.text:
detective fiction and the implicit – and
I say implicit rather than explicit – political

639.05.text:
dimension of many of the stories in where
the plots hinge on experiences of occupation,

645.30.text:
life under dictatorship, stories of collaboration
with the enemy, organised crime, Government

651.63.text:
corruption and most recently, migration and
people trafficking, all of which is a very

656.69.text:
very long way away from Baker Street or the
English village.

663.43.text:
So if it is indeed the case that crime fiction
captures the history of the period, then the

668.53.text:
English tradition established by Conan Doyle
and Agatha Christie, if we can call it a tradition,

674.52.text:
reflects a very different history from the
rest of Europe, which of course is evident

679.08.text:
today in the highly ambiguous English relationship

686.76.text:
of course that Christie does make Poirot a

and hints that Jane Marple has never married

702.53.text:
with – it wasn’t a fiancé, I think she

705.79.text:
she was in love with was killed in the first

709.70.text:
Now a very famous essay of 1948 that appeared
in Harpers Magazine, WH Auden declared himself

716.86.text:
an addict of detective stories. He explained
his addiction by listing what he saw as two

723.01.text:
essential criteria: firstly the novel must
conform to specific formula and it must convey

732.41.text:
a sense of immediacy that would compel the
reader to read on with urgency, and I think

738.80.text:
that’s actually really quite interesting,
that notion of the detective novel being written

744.77.text:
in such a way that one reads almost compulsively.
He calls his essay ‘The Guilty Vicarage’

752.23.text:
and says that he finds it very difficult to
read a detective story that’s not set in

760.34.text:
The task of the detective, according to Auden,
is “to restore a state of grace in which

766.89.text:
the aesthetic and the ethical are as one”.
For Auden, detective fiction is definitely

774.04.text:
escapist writing in which there is the magical
satisfaction of the illusion of being dissociated

781.92.text:
from the murderer and again, he’s writing
in 1948 so of course one of the writers that

788.33.text:
he challenges in that essay is Raymond Chandler,
another hugely successful writer but certainly

795.17.text:
by no means an escapist writer in the way
of Agatha Christie. But he actually says Chandler’s

803.54.text:
“extremely depressing books should be judged
not as escapist fiction but as works of art”.

811.69.text:
What of course Auden couldn’t foresee is
how his binary distinction between types of

817.54.text:
detective fiction would actually continue
to widen and widen and the detective story

823.78.text:
is developed in very different social contexts.
But of course Auden was writing from the safety

830.53.text:
of the United States, at a distance from the
traumas of post-war Europe. He was also writing

838.58.text:
in an age – 1948 remember – when all the
challenges to the high canon brought about

844.88.text:
by feminist deconstruction, post-colonialism
etc, had not happened, hence literature was

850.65.text:
still divided into what was then termed the
Great Works and what the Germans called ‘trivialliteratur’

857.06.text:
which included detective fiction, romantic
fiction, children’s fiction, memoires and

861.00.text:
a whole host of other popular writing. And
yet, as Andre LeFevre pointed out years ago

868.98.text:
in his book that looks at the many agencies
behind the movement of texts within and across

875.96.text:
cultures, the translation, rewriting and the
manipulation of literary fame, the vast majority

881.73.text:
of readers are what he calls ‘non-professional
readers’. I quote, “it is my contention”,

889.36.text:
says LeFevre, “that the process resulting
in the acceptance or rejection, canonisation

895.68.text:
on non-canonisation of literary works, is
dominated not by vague but by very concrete

902.15.text:
factors that are easy to discern as soon as
one decides to look for them. That is, as

908.69.text:
soon as one eschews interpretation that the
core of literary studies and begins to address

913.93.text:
such issues as power, ideology, institution
and manipulation” as we’ve been hearing

920.89.text:
in the presentations earlier this afternoon.
He also points out, somewhat contentiously,

929.19.text:
that so-called high literature is increasingly
read only in educational settings, that is

934.67.text:
in schools and universities, and does not
constitute the preferred reading matter of

939.31.text:
the non-professional reader. For it’s the
non-professional reader who buys the books

944.47.text:
that make the best-selling list and drives
up the sales figures into millions.

948.52.text:
Now LeFevre is obviously trying to make a
case for broadening literary studies to include

954.30.text:
the study of all forms of re-writing – translations,
anthologies, literary histories, reviews,

959.69.text:
editions, films and television versions, abridgements,
plots – all of these different versions.

970.72.text:
Because most readers, according to LeFevre,
even those who can be termed ‘professional

975.02.text:
readers’ have some kind of construct of
a literary work in their heads. So in his

981.95.text:
view, say War and Peace, would be based not

987.98.text:
on a combination of plot summary, opinion,
maybe film adaptation, maybe television adaptation,

994.24.text:
that they’ve acquired over time and for

998.48.text:
this, I always use Charles Dickens as a case

1005.66.text:
and everybody would have heard of Charles

1009.64.text:

1014.49.text:
age – of having read one of those novels

well everyone’s seen the film of the musical.

novel but still you know that Dickens’ Oliver

1031.99.text:
bowl and dares to ask for more gruel. So it’s

1037.38.text:
these high texts that are at the same time

Now non-professional readers of detective
fiction appear, if we follow Auden’s binary

distinction, to enjoy both the escapist variety

contemporary detective fiction if we look

at the sales figures which continue, the continued

1065.63.text:
sales figures for people like Patricia Highsmith

that there are non-professional readers who

Now since the 1990s when LeFevre’s book

publishing and in the global distribution

1088.74.text:

1094.80.text:
changes in taste and I would say that one

1101.77.text:
of detective fiction around the world, accompanied

1108.16.text:
some not. And with this has come a much higher
status for detective fiction. One’s seen

1114.67.text:
very much as a marginalised genre and I put

in terms of when I said why I started getting

1127.36.text:
in European detective fiction. When I was

prize some dozen years ago and then three

was getting up for 400 novels – with some

In fact, I would actually go so far as to

1226.40.text:

not romantic novels, not fantasy novels, but

as she points out, there's a very large number

for their work straight away. Yet within a

writers like – I made a little list, I went

is another good example of the unpredictability

Now in his seminal essay on the position of

1457.81.text:
Evans O’Hare proposed a basic novel, a modern

1464.58.text:
basic model for tracing and understanding

1469.07.text:
linguistic frontiers. The terminology of that

1475.52.text:
still valid is the point that he made about

1481.35.text:
different historical moments. Under certain
conditions, literary systems import ideas

1488.52.text:
or forms that result in the creation of new

1494.34.text:
out his three principle conditions when this

1505.11.text:
what he was saying is when there seems to

1517.45.text:
are points when established models are no

1522.71.text:
come back to Dickens, the Dickens novel, that

1527.72.text:

1540.99.text:
history from a translationist perspective,

1554.06.text:
O’Hare’s work has given rise to a lot

1557.86.text:
national literary histories, though a lot

1564.22.text:
quite a lot of work, I think things are changing

1569.57.text:
works. I think the shift at the moment is

There have been a number of extraordinary

1586.46.text:
phenomena that have come up out of nowhere,

the Twilight vampire books which I’ve already

– Game of Thrones and most remarkable of

of these have been success stories that have

very rapidly from, let’s say, local to global

Let me go back to Agatha Christie though.
What’s apparent is that she was writing

1628.69.text:
in a way that appealed to her contemporary
readers and somehow continues to do so, which

1635.32.text:
is another interesting question, because Christie’s
writing is not – anybody read any Agatha

1641.19.text:
Christie novels? – yeah, one you see. A

1650.08.text:

1663.92.text:
final denouement, readers are led down blind

1668.54.text:
great moment of revelation. What I find interesting

1675.04.text:
ways very theatrical and I think that theatricality,

1680.59.text:
one reason why they work so well on television

1686.60.text:
well for the one or two hour television format.
But in Christie’s work, no matter how many

1692.43.text:
people die, no matter how brutal the murders
which are never described in the kind of detail

1697.98.text:
that we get from many of our contemporary
writers, there’s always the final resolution

1703.64.text:
and that final resolution, as Auden puts it
in his Guilty Vicarage essay, “the detective

1709.88.text:
story addict is restored to a state of innocence
in the Garden of Eden. The reader’s ultimate

1715.84.text:
fantasy of escape”. There’s another thing
about Christie, she locates her narratives

1721.66.text:
in a particular milieu. A milieu is upper
class England. Her characters move in high

1728.79.text:
social circles with titled aristocracy and

1735.63.text:
it’s a fantasy of a world as foreign to
her readers as the Pyramids of Egypt. And

1742.15.text:
apparently the interest in Egypt, so I understand,
is because after her marriage to an archaeologist,

1747.87.text:
she did a certain amount of travelling and
became absolutely fascinated and so kept weaving

1754.67.text: the Nile and Egypt into some of her stories.

1757.55.text:
But it occurs to me that it’s possible that
one of the attractions of Christie’s fiction

1764.60.text:
today and really since she first began to
acquire this global success, is that idealised

1772.47.text:
Englishness, which is packaged in such a way
as to be accessible both to English and non-English

1778.53.text:
readers, and this accessibility contrasts
for example with the novels of Dorothy Sayers.

1785.55.text:
Dorothy Sayers, her contemporary whose sleuth,
Lord Peter Whimsey, is a kind of caricature

1791.81.text:
of upper Englishness, upper class Englishness.
Auden described him as a priggish superman

1800.91.text:
by the way. Auden didn’t like him at all.
But in order to understand Sayers novels,

1808.97.text:
you do actually have to have some understanding
of some of the nuances of the English class

1813.07.text:
system which you don’t with Christie. You
can see exactly the same fantastical idealised

1819.07.text:
England in the hugely successful Inspector
Barnaby, the Midsomer Murders programmes,

1826.29.text:
which are sold everywhere - apparently Angela
Merkel’s favourite programme so one hears,

1833.14.text:
hugely, hugely successful in the Nordic countries.
Midsomer Murders has gone through eighteen

1839.42.text:
series, has been sold to 225 different countries
and in 2015, I don’t know if any of you

1846.66.text:
saw this, there was an Anglo-Danish episode
of Midsomer Murders that brought together

1853.10.text:
two of the Danish actresses who have been
well-known through the Nordic Noir series,

1859.04.text:
with Barnaby and his sidekick. It’s true!
Look it up and you’ll find it. Ann Eleonora

1867.72.text:
Jørgensen from ‘The Killing’ and Birgitte
Hjort Sørensen from ‘Borgen’, both appear

1872.93.text:
in an episode when Barnaby and his sidekick
go to Copenhagen. So it’s actually quite

1882.13.text:
entertaining to see the way in which this
has been put together. But Midsomer Murders,

1887.52.text:
like Agatha Christie’s writing, offers a
very safe space where murders happen but order

1892.30.text:
is always restored and the order is reinforced
by the idealised rural English setting. And

1899.62.text:
it seems to me that it’s that fantasy of
Englishness that continues to appeal as much,

1904.40.text:
if not more, than the absolutely ridiculous
plots of pasteboard characters.

1909.32.text:
Five minutes? Yeah. Beside the lavish country
house settings of Christie’s stories, some

1920.41.text:
of them are set in luxurious hotels and I
think here we can see the tendency of another

1925.12.text:
strand, another kind of contemporary detective
fiction which is the location in which the

1930.84.text:
stories take place. Lawson argues that some
detective fiction operates as a kind of imaginative

1939.02.text:
travel agency, taking readers across borders
and introducing them to other cultures. Location

1944.45.text:
is very important in the Inspector Chen books
by Qiu Xiaolong – has anybody read any Inspector

1952.70.text:
Chen? There's Keigo Higashino detective, Kyoichiro
Kaga and you get details here of contemporary

1962.12.text:
Chinese and Japanese society which actually
is compensation for what are, certainly in

1968.30.text:
all the novels I’ve read, very weak plot
lines and very stilted, very strange, English.

1976.69.text:
But interestingly, the cover blurbs for these
novelists use the device of associating Chinese

1982.76.text:
and Japanese writers with well-known European
figures. So you have Inspector Chen described

1987.67.text: as ‘the Morse of the Far East’.

1991.22.text:
While Higashino is ‘the Japanese Stieg Larsson’.
So part of the sales pitch is to try and hook

2004.63.text:
the Chinese and Japanese detective writers
with these well-known Europeans. And of course

2013.36.text:
Michael Dibdin’s detective novels are set
in Italy, as are Donna Leon’s and we were

2020.87.text:
hearing earlier about the seem to be rather
extraordinary visits to Naples to look round

2029.59.text:
Eleanor Ferrante’s patch but there are certainly
well-established tours to Montalbano’s Sicily

2038.03.text:
which do include visits to certain restaurants
and these are extremely popular with fans

2047.77.text:
Now Camilleri, I’ll come onto Camilleri
before I finish, Camilleri began writing detective

2053.41.text:
fiction in his late 60s. His first Montalbano
novel came out in 1994 and in an interview

2062.46.text:
which was then translated and published in
The Guardian, Camilleri explains how he came

2067.80.text:
to write novels that would engage with some
of the major social problems of his native

2072.87.text:
Sicily. He’s very explicit that he’s writing
social novels - Government corruption, power

2077.83.text:
of the Mafia, the drug cartels, people trafficking
– and a climate of violence and terror which

2084.03.text:
in his view had not existed since the immediate
post-war period in the 1940s. I quote, “I

2092.52.text:
deliberately decided to smuggle into detective
stories a critical commentary on my own times”.

2098.56.text:
Part of his strategy is to write the novels
in a mixture of standard Italian, Sicilian

2105.59.text:
dialect and a Sicilian variant of Italian
and to shift between these three linguistic

2111.05.text:
registers, well aware that he’s dealing
with shifting power relations as he does so.

2116.64.text:
And he says, “the dialect is always confidential,
a non-institutional relationship, intimate,

2123.64.text:
a friendly atmosphere, whereas the use of
the Italian language creates an immediate

2129.27.text:
officialness, a distance. It is used to make
law, to suggest intimidation, power, distance,

2135.11.text:
emphasis” and the Sicilian location is essential
to his novels, not just as a colourful backdrop

2142.69.text:
but as a real place where the struggle between
the State and organised corruption is played

2147.60.text:
out every day. Camilleri’s deliberate use
of these linguistic registers is a conscious

2153.94.text:
attempt to smuggle critical commentary on
his own time, but of course the English translator,

2161.15.text:
Steven Santorelli, was faced with the impossible
task of finding equivalents and so pretty

2166.72.text:
well opts for standard English throughout,
except for the character of the stupid Catarella

2171.76.text:
who speaks in a sort of inventive language
that’s part cockney, part Bronx. Whatever

2178.18.text:
it is, it’s a literary language devoid of
any political significance and it seems to

2183.12.text:
me quite interesting that Camilleri’s novels
in English, which have been very successful,

2187.70.text:
lose their political significance and so fit
into the escapist category. You can even look

2194.32.text:
at the covers – I should have brought a
couple with me – the English versions have

2198.14.text:
brightly coloured covers, they’re very plain,
the Italian’s very plain covers. Camilleri

2204.95.text:
the political novelist is repackaged in English
as a writer of escapist fiction in a holiday

2211.09.text:
I’m coming to my conclusion. The success
of the Nordic detective fiction though has

2218.24.text:
led to the republication of the godparents
of Nordic Noir, Maj Sjöwall and Per Wahlöö.

2224.67.text:
They were a husband and wife team, both communists,
writing in the 1960s and their novels revealed

2231.87.text:
a darker side to the image of the idealised
Swedish welfare state. Their detective, Martin

2238.45.text:
Beck, is an unheroic figure with a private
life that’s far from perfect, bored with

2244.26.text:
his job, depressed by the misery and the violence
he keeps encountering, suffers from dyspepsia,

2249.76.text:
but of course he’s widely acknowledged as
the prototype for the whole string of Nordic

2255.80.text:
detectives who follow on. In a preface to
the novel Roseanna reissued in 2006, first

2265.47.text:
published in 1965, Henning Mankell says this,
“I think that anyone who writes about crime

2273.05.text:
as a reflection of society has been inspired
to some extent by what they wrote. They broke

2279.33.text:
with the previous trends in crime fiction,
broke with the hopelessly stereotyped character

2285.06.text:
descriptions that were so prevalent” and
Shaun and Nicky French writing a preface in

2292.88.text:
2007 to another of their novels republished
point out that the Martin Beck books succeed

2300.33.text:
as social commentary, as well as detective
stories. I quote “because despite it all,

2307.36.text:
despite politics that are as far-removed from
the reactionary Christie as is possible to

2312.18.text:
get, Sjöwall and Wahlöö never lost their
pleasure in the machinery of the whodunit”.

2317.62.text:
So in my view the global success of detective
fiction is a very complex phenomenon but the

2326.03.text:
binary distinction made somewhat patronisingly
by WH Auden does appear to have some credibility.

2331.34.text:
The continued success of formulaic, reactionary
writers like Agatha Christie and her many

2339.12.text:
successors, has to be offset against the global
success of those writers who are more politically

2345.14.text:
engaged and who use the format of the detective
novel as much more than simple plot resolution.

2352.80.text:
I think this division is particularly apparent
when we consider the unexpected popularity

2357.74.text:
of Nordic Noir which demonstrates a different
taste of design on the part of the non-professional

2363.92.text:
reader for a different kind of detective fiction.
That Camilleri should have been translated

2370.08.text:
in such a way, and you might notice if you’ve
seen any of the programmes, they’re dubbed

2376.08.text:
into standard English as well so the standard
English – not dubbed, they’re subtitled

2382.64.text:
in standard English – what happens is that
the multi-layered and ideologically charged

2391.42.text:
Europeans are living in a time of immense
social and political changes and the detective

2396.23.text:
story format seems to be providing a useful
frame for exploring what’s going on at grass

2402.68.text:
roots level. The idealised Nordic states have
been shown to have much darker undercurrents.

2408.87.text:
Political and judicial corruption reached
its Nadia in Berlusconi’s Italy. The unresolved

2414.01.text:
pain of the end of the Franco era without
a process of truth and reconciliation continues

2419.60.text:
to haunt Spanish writers, just as the break-up
of Yugoslavia and the atrocities of the Balkan

2426.19.text:
wars continued to haunt Serbian, Croatian
and Slovene writers. Stories of war-time collaboration

2434.06.text:
with the Nazis continued to come to light,
as do stories of paedophilia in the Catholic

2440.58.text:
church. In Britain, the rise of Scottish independence
raise the possibility of the end of the union.

2447.68.text:
The euro lurches from crisis to crisis and
today, images of the suffering of millions

2452.72.text:
of refugees displaced by wars outside Europe,
created by Europeans in the Middle East and

2461.19.text:
North Africa, appear daily on our television
screens. The term ‘people trafficking’,

2465.19.text:
think about it, it didn’t exist a few years
ago. It’s now entered into absolute daily

2470.55.text:
parlays. And since major socio-political changes
always, always, have epistemological consequence,

2477.23.text:
it may well be that the rise of detective
fiction, both in terms of sales figures and

2484.57.text:
its changing status, is indicative of something
that non-professional readers are reaching

2490.89.text:
out to. Some of our non-professional readers
favour the dark gruesome variants, others

2497.59.text:
opt for escapism, but both are opting increasingly
for the detective story format and it seems

2505.23.text:
to me that those of us – all of us in this
room who are professional readers – would

2510.38.text: do well to take note. Thank you.
